Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding Space Through Engineering Design investigates how engaging K-5 children from underrepresented populations in the design of packages, maps, and mechanisms supports the development of spatial reasoning and spatial mathematics. The prime conjecture is that engineering design makes spatial mathematics more tangible and purposeful, and that systematic support for spatial reasoning and mathematics, in turn, influences the nature of children's designs and their understanding of how those designs work. The project, therefore, serves as a test bed to explore the promises and challenges of an integrated STEM education.

Research methods include intensive close-up study of small groups of children designers led by researchers, followed by larger-scale study of classroom implementations led by elementary teachers. The purpose of the work with small groups of students across grades is to enable the project investigators to learn about the accessibility, challenge, and interest that engineering design holds for youngsters and to inform subsequent steps in revising the instruction for classroom tryouts. The classroom implementations provide data about how engineering design supports mathematical growth and, in turn, how growth in mathematical understanding guides subsequent engineering design. As children design and share their designs, mathematical and engineering practices, such as definition, conjecture, and troubleshooting, emerge in classroom conversation, often when children compare variations in the artifacts that they create. Researchers seek relationships between the emergence of these practices and changes in students' learning; in this way, relations between doing and knowing can be established. Forms of data include video recording of episodes of student design and classroom conversations. In addition, researchers conduct interviews with students to assess their understanding of how the artifacts they create work. The interviews particularly emphasize the role that spatial mathematics plays in students' explanations of device function and in their accounts of design processes. The progress of the project, including curriculum development, interview construction, and data analysis will be overseen by a five-member advisory board that includes a evaluation specialist, a mathematician, a mathematics educator, and a design expert.

The project will contribute to a beginning knowledge base about how integrated STEM education can best be pursued, in particular, by exposing the possibilities and challenges inherent in the proposed emphasis on engineering design. By working closely with 18 teachers and their 500 students, the project investigators aim to develop a practical, yet powerful approach to iSTEM education, that is, a new study of integrated science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Products include a website featuring a suite of curriculum materials, case episodes of children designing, and formative assessments of children's learning in contexts of everyday classroom activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding Space Through Engineering Design investigated the development of K-5 children’s reasoning about the nature of space and its measure (length, angle, area, volume). To study and support children’s development, we formed a research-practice partnership with 18 elementary teachers at a school in rural Arkansas that serves underrepresented youth, including large numbers of immigrants from Mexico and the Pacific Islands. Together, teachers and researchers generated and tested the viability of a learning progression to help children develop understanding of the mathematics of measure. A learning progression identifies major milestones of conceptual development, in this case, in the measurement of angle, length, area, and volume. It included curricular materials that teachers and researchers co-constructed and employed in classrooms to support students’ conceptual change. The learning progression encompassed many of the milestones of conceptual development identified during the previous two decades of research in the field. In addition, uniquely, it supported learning by (a) introducing children to forms of measurement involving embodied motion, such as measuring lengths by literally or by imagining traveling between landmarks; and (b) challenging children to either invent or reverse-engineer standard tools of measure, such as a protractor.  Embodied motions provided integrating metaphors that underpinned the entire curriculum. They included one dimensional travel to reify measure of length as distance along a path, two-dimensional sweep (movement of one length through another) to generate area and units of area measure, three-dimensional sweep of area through length to generate volume and units of volume measure, and rotation in two dimensions to generate and measure angles-as-turns. These embodied motions were recruited to help students interpret measures as continuous quantities. In turn, this emphasis on reasoning about continuous quantities supported children’s thinking about fractions and arithmetic operations involving fractions. For example, children who initially struggled with how fractions could be greater than one, found this idea to be quite sensible when they imagined traveling in fractional units between landmarks with distances that exceeded 1 unit. Similarly, in area measure, children who initially could not understand how a fractional length (e.g., ½ u) multiplied by another fractional length (e.g., 1/2 u) could result in an area with a magnitude less than either length could visualize this result (e.g., ½ u2 ) after working on sweeping activities with concrete materials, like squeeges and paint, and with a technological application designed to further support the sweeping metaphor.

 

Each strand of conceptual development in the learning progression was represented as a construct (a list of typical benchmarks of development), so that teachers could implement construct-centered formative assessment during the course of instruction. Constructs in the measure of length, area, volume, and angle represented and ordered significant milestones in children’s learning, so that teachers could orient instruction toward supporting students to develop increasingly sophisticated ways of thinking and acting. We conducted yearly interviews with teachers about their experiences instructing children in ideas about measure and geometry. There was a significant expansion in teachers’ views of the mathematical meanings of measure and considerable change in their perspectives on effective teaching practices over time. These changes were accompanied by increases in children’s learning.

 

Motion also played a pivotal role in students’ learning about geometry by making it possible for teachers to build from students’ pre-existing intuitive understanding of the way bodies and objects move in space to develop increasingly mathematical ideas about space. Children in kindergarten, first grade, and second grade learned about isometries (reflections and rotations) and symmetries (e.g., reflections and rotations that did not change the appearance of a structure) in two and three dimensions. Reasoning about isometry and symmetry was supported by engaging children in defining isometries and symmetries and in designing with isometries and symmetries in mind. In two dimensions, children designed frieze patterns, such as those commonly seen on the borders of walls of rooms) and in three dimensions, structures made with simple building tools that met symmetry constraints, e.g., design a structure with only ½ turn symmetry. The emphases on design and defining also helped children reason about relations between reflections and rotations. This emphasis on intrinsic symmetry was extended with older children to include symmetry as a tool for analyzing and constructing properties of space on planes, cylinders, spheres, and hyperbolic planes (surfacees with negative curvature, like a leaf of lettuce or a saddle). Children imagined an ant’s perspective to travel (move and turn) along lines (geodesics) on these different surfaces to experience how some properties of polygons, such as triangles and squares, remained invariant, while others changed. For example, in the fifth grade, some students realized that “the sphere is doing some of the turning” to explain why the exterior angle sum of triangles was never 360 degrees—which meant that the interior sum of the triangles they identified always exceeded 180 degrees.
